4. Robinsons Galleria: Located just up the road from SM City. Has a decent hotel attached to the complex (summit galleria) . Has a tgifridays AND denny's (many memories of drunken fights at 3am in my local dennys in Miami.....here in the Philippines its a "classy" resturant LOOOL).

5. Robinsons Fuente: Located in Osmena circle, right up the street from the infamous mango square. On the first floor, theirs a vendor who sells "TOBACCO" pipes and rolling papers.....other than that it's not much in there except your standard fastfood and grocery store.

6. Parkmall: Located in Mandaue adjacent to BAI hotel. Mixed indoor/outdoor mall with a grocery store and lots of food options. Major transportation hub for PUV's. Good people watching in the afternoon for a more local flavor

7. City Times square: This can be considered part of parkmall as it right across the street. Outdoor stripmall type......has a few good bars and restaurants attached. Queensland hotel is here as well, for all your short time boomboom needs.

8. Pacific mall MANDAUE: Located just off the bridge coming from lapulapu city. Medium sized mall with your standard Jolibee/chowking offerings. Transportation hub for those headed into the northern suburbs of cebu

9. J Centre Mall (Jmall): Medium sized mall located in Mandaue. Most notable feature is their Bureau of Immigration office. If you live here as a foreigner for a while you will need to come here eventually. Decent hotel attached, and a nice bar (SENTRAL) located 1 minute walk away.

10. Elizabeth mall (Emall): Located adjacent to the south bus terminal. Smaller mall. Has a ghetto public school (ACT) attached, good place to people watch. For some reason I see ALOT of Africans in this mall, I can't fucking explain it, but I'm working on figuring it out.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2368785
11. Ayala Central Block: Newer mall situated in IT park across the street from the park social and sugbu mercado. Lots of call center people open to foreigners around this area. Make sure to tell your driver AYALA in IT PARK, because if you just say "Ayala" they will take you to the Ayala center for sure.
12. JY Centre: Smaller mall in the Lahug neighborhood with a few food options, and a Mcdonalds for the Amerimutts. This is mainly used a jump off point for those going up into the mountains to see the TOPS viewpoint. Lots of motortaxi drivers will hang out here and try to take you up the mountain on a tour

13. Gaisano country mall: Outdoor Shopping area located in Mandaue. I've driven by this many times but never went in, so I can't really report as to what's there, but it IS THERE.

14. Gaisano Main/138 mall/Colonade: I've included these all together as they are in the same general vicinity (walking distance). All three of these are on, or very near to Colon street. Most Gaisano "malls" are not really malls so to speak, but more like big department stores. 138 and colonade sell a bunch of cheap knockoff shit from China, but theirs some good looking girls in there I'LL TELL YOU WHATTTTT

15.Gaisano Tisa/Gaisano jai alai/Gaisano mandaue central/Gaisano mandaue north: YEA theirs like 10 of these things in the greater Cebu area, I'm sure I'm missing some, so cebuBros correct me if I'm missing anything. These are more ghetto malls, your gonna see lots of flip flops, basketball shorts, knockoff basketball jerseys, and ankle bracelets. No frills here, this is a mall for locals.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2369016
16. SM Consalacion: Smaller Sm mall located on the northern outskirts of Cebu. Kind of out the way if your staying in the city center, but it's the last stop before you start heading into the northern provinces.

17. Marina Mall: Located in LapuLapu city. This is mall in closet proximity to the airport. Standard jolibee/ chowking affair, nothing special. Their is another mall across the street (it's a gaisano mall), but as their is ANOTHER gaisano mall located a few meters down the road, I refer to both as Marina mall. The drivers have lived in the neighbnorhood their whole life and they still get the 2 malls mixed up, so just say Marina mall.

18. Gaisano Island mall: Located on lapu lapu a few meters from marina mall.....Known locally as Island mall. Theirs a beauru of immigration office inside, so if you live in lapulapu, its much more convient than going all the way into the city for your visa extensions.

19. Tamiya: This is an outdoor outlet style mall. On google maps, this is marked as "THE SHOPS AT PUEBLO VERDE", or "PUEBLO VERDE". If you tell a driver to take you to Pueblo verde, he will look at you like your stupid. For some reason everyone calls this area tamiya, you have to say tamiya or they won't know where the fuck you're talking about. I have many fond memories in Tamiya. Pre-pandemic they used to have a disco and a restobar in here, and I picked up quite a few girls just drinking in front of the 7/11 there (not hookers just horny young women). It's a bit more subdued now, but it's still a major transportation hub for LapuLapu city and they have several large factories nearby, so this place gets packed with people in the late afternoon. LOTS OF BEAUTIFUL GIRLS who work in factories making 200 dollars a month praying and hoping you'll save them can be found in this area. Try to brighten up their life, but don't take advantage please.

21. Grandmall Cordova: It's not a mall, its a fucking department store. Somebody told me that if you go to the 7/11 just down the street in poblacion (just tell kuya 7/11 poblacion), horny girls will come to you and PICK YOU UP if you wait around long enough. LOL

name: Walking Tanzanian
com:
So I'm thinking of leaving tomorrow and trek through my country, Tanzania. Any advice on cross-country walking? I'll leave my phone and everything behind. Carry a backpack and a few clothes and some things to lie on and cover myself, a container for food I buy along the way, and a 2 Litre bottle of water. I'll post a don't worry message on Twitter, and have about $2000 in my bank account(which is a lot in Tanzania) and will be withdrawing little by little at ATMs.

Why am I doing this? After my last suicide attempt life has been feeling pointless. I dropped out of university and have been blaming myself for not making the suicide work. I always believe the universe is so big, you can choose to minimize your gaze and focus on the little you can control, or expand your horizons and explore. I've done the former for so long and it hasn't left me satisfied, might as well try the latter for a change. I hope in this journey I find a reason to live, or a reason not to, but regardless, I owe myself to try.

I'm currently in Bukoba(picrel), I'm thinking of following the paved trunk roads and sleeping alongside it all the way to Dar es salaam. I'll try to stay at most 2 days without food before I consider taking a small bus to the closest town.

Anyway. Any advice on cross-country walking?

Do you have a water filter? If not, get one. Because Africa water is full of deadly disease you may need a virus filter which Costs a lot. You need a big face net
Get a knife, something you can use to fashion fixes and stuff with,

name: Anonymous
com: How have social media and the Internet specifically changed the travelling experience?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Access to information you previously had to carry in books like Lonely Planet
Real time information, such as flight cancellations, possible problems in your destination - weather/natural disasters/conflict
Much more flexible and reliable methods to make bookings, you're not relying on travel agents to set you up in a hotel
Arguably better prices - you can see competitive pricing that was hidden from you before
The chance to communicate with people in country ahead of time and communicate with family back home without waiting on mail or paying an obscene amount for international calls.
And yeah, social media has ruined a lot of destinations by over popularising them with people who would otherwise not know about them. People take a stupid amount of photos for the gram, some would argue that many people are travelling to destinations for the pictures and not for their own sake.
For the individual, the internet is indisputably a good thing for travel, but for a lot of destinations its just led to social and environmental disaster.

Going to the beach to a place like Guaruja from SP is doable in a daytrip. That said, its not a good place nowadays and since you'll go to Rio is not worth imho. There's Paranapiacaba, which may be nice for a local to take a look at village built by the english railworks in the XIX century but I also don't think is anything special for a foreign tourist. There's some trails in parque da cantareira, one of the biggest urban parks in the world. It can take half a day to do the longest one and since you like fitness stuff it may be worth to hike it. There's some nice views from the observatory. You could uber there from where you are or take the tube to the first station (northernmost) of the blue line and uber from there.
If you want to drive and leave the city, you could go to Campos do Jordão, where there is also some hiking. This city is famous due to having a high altitude (brazilian standards) and used as a winter destination for paulistanos (people from the city of SP). Besides it I don't think there's any city worth visiting by the city itself.
I mean, you could hike in lots of places and do stuff like rafting in Brotas or go parachuting in Boituva. That's pretty much it, though.
Most of our countryside has nothing really interesting. We just go there to our country houses, to some festivities when we know locals from those cities or if we have some activity in mind.
Like I said before Ilhabela is very nice. But its a good place to spend some days, at least a weekend. Daytrip would be really tiresome. Paraty, a city between Rio and SP, is also very nice. Colonial buildings, nice islands, great for boating and with some /out/ stuff. But would also demand some days as it takes about 4 hours to reach by car.

name: Dylan
sub: Is traveling really worth the hassle and cost?
com:
Has anybody else become disillusioned with travel? Everyone shows off the glamorous side of traveling on social media when that's just a small part of the experience. Most of it is negative. There's the constant waiting, security checkpoints, boarding and deboarding packed planes, cramped seating with minimal legroom, surly flight attendants, long customs and immigration lines, currency exchange, language barriers, awkward situations and faux pas, hawkers persistently pestering you, corrupt police shaking you down, robbers targeting you as a tourist, food poisoning, motion sickness, uncomfortable weather that you aren't used to, crowds just about everywhere with 8 billion people on the planet. It's all so tiresome. Usually I need a vacation from my vacation when it's all over.

All for what? I can order all sorts of ethnic food in my city. I can date women from different cultural backgrounds here. I can use the internet or VR device to see the Eiffel Tower, Statue of Liberty and old dusty churches. I can visit museums virtually. I can learn about a country's history online. I can drive to beaches and nature. No need to travel across the globe for any of this. I wish I had realized this earlier in life before I wasted so much money on pointless travel. I would rather use the money towards a lakeside retreat home away from the city.

Depends what you are looking for

Cities here are much less Aesthetic than you can find on the Continent, only Bath stands out off the top of my head.

There aren't really any tourist attractions in other cities, unless you are a fan of history in which case there are numerous Cathedrals and Castles, as well as ruined Abbeys, Castles and Roman stuff. However the latter are in remote areas not hugely accessible by train.

That being said, aesthetic and comfy small towns and villages are in veritable abundance.
So if you want to experience the spirit of 'Old England' I would strongly recommend going to the Cotswolds if this is your thing.

As others have said London is a complete shit tip, but there are some worthwhile things to see, you've got the classic landmarks like Westminster Abbey and the Houses of Parliament. There are other great attractions such as the British Museum and National Portrait Gallery which are free and house lots of well known and remarkable stuff.

I like lots of meat and milk and not much else, which is expensive as fuck if you eat out, so I got a small electric pot and boil meat with some vegetables and sauces you can find in the grocery store. If you check out different shops you can often find cheap tuna and salmon sashimi as well. Theres a bunch of different grocery stores, so shop around, you can find prepared tuna under 300円/100g and salmon under 400円 pretty easily.

nuuk -> Dash-8 200 (ECONOMY) -> keflavik, iceland ($470)
>taxi
from airport to hotel: 200dkk ($28)

25dkk ($3.50) per ride

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2367619
Did a ton of walking. Walked all of Kangerlussuaq in my 4 hour layover there, and walked all of Nuuk in my 2 weeks there. The Nuuk "metro" area is made up of like 3 sub-cities with a bus system connecting them. Assuming whether is permitting (it rained or snowed every other day), there are ample sidewalks and trails to go just about everywhere.
The locals seemed to frown on people leaving the city and exploring outside of the city. Maybe they're tired of tourists getting themselves in trouble or whatever.
There are also ferries that stop off at random villages that you can use to explore, though they weren't running while I was there.
>>2367699
Did not see it in my time in Nuuk (though there isn't much light pollution, and def far enough north, so it seems possible). Seen them numerous times in Alaska, and you're right, most of the time it's just a haze of one color, typically green, purple, yellow/orange. Very rarely do they dance like you see in timelapse videos or whatever.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2367659
Touched on in my previous posts a bit already, but:
>logistics
>How easy was it to get there and back?
As far as I can tel, the only way to get to Greenland is via either Keflavik, Iceland (Reykjavik's airport), or Copenhagen via Air Greenland's A330 passenger jet.
I did see one plane with a with a Canadian livery, so presumably they fly to Kangerlussuaq from somewhere in Nunavut.
>What about getting around?
Public transit (ie busses) only exist in Nuuk it seems. Walking, biking, snowmachining, 4 wheelers, and cars are the primary forms of travel. Nuuk also had taxis, and Kangerlussuaq had a shuttle operating between the airport and town center.
>Was it easy to book a place to stay?
My experience might be unique, but the my hotel's website wasn't working and I was forced to call and email with the hotel's front desk. The 2 or 3 other hotels seemed to operate the same. So, not terrible, but not ideal.
>How was the internet and did you shitpost on a 4chan board with flags?
Internet was exceptional. Wifi in my room hovered around the 100-200mb mark for down, and like 75 for up. Genuinely impressed with the internet and cell service infrastructure they have there. Our Danish friends must be helping out. And yes, I did. Every niche place I go I always make time to post from >flag

Svalbard is another place to consider. Flights are better. Next place on the list is the Antarctic...

name: Anonymous
com:
Hopefully not a hard ask, but are there any aussie anons on this board that know much about interstate travel? Is there a general laundry list of things to be aware of?

Some specific questions:

If you go interstate by train, how long in advance should you book tickets?
Why do some flights between capitals cost less than some trains/ferries?
Are busses a better option than trains?
What occurs at interstate checkpoints and how much time is wasted at them?
If I work for cash/keep a lot of cash on me, how much money can I carry onto a plane before the people at the airport suspect I'm Pablo Escobar?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2366333
>If you go interstate by train, how long in advance should you book tickets?
I've never travelled interstate by train. Australia is not so great for long distance train travel, we don't have high speed trains like Europe or Asia. So a simple trip from Sydney to Melbourne can take like 11 or 12 hours by train, whereas it takes 90 minutes in the air. For this reason most people fly, only poorfags or very elderly people take the train.
>Why do some flights between capitals cost less than some trains/ferries?
Train and coach are usually cheap. But flights are reasonable because plenty of competition, lots of available seats and demand. Of course it also depends on the route and the time of the year.
>Are busses a better option than trains?
I've never been interstate on train so I can't make a good comparison. But when I was a poorfag student I did go down to Melbourne via coach and it was an overnight trip, it took about 12 hours. The bus make about two stops along the way at big roadside petrol station/truckstops. So you can get off the bus, stretch your legs, take a piss and buy a snack.
>What occurs at interstate checkpoints and how much time is wasted at them?
Nothing. If you fly the only 'checkpoint' as such will be airport security. If you drive then it is pretty much nothing. Sometimes between NSW and QLD they warn you not to bring in fresh fruit from interstate, but I've never actually seen a roadside checkpoint enforcing this.
>how much money can I carry onto a plane
When you enter Australia as an international passenger then you will need to declare if you are carrying more than $10,000 in cash, cabin crew will give you an incoming passenger card on your arriving flight and the card will tell you what you need to declare. Once you are in Australia and travelling between states on domestic flights then I'm not aware of any limits on cash.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2366400
>what level of sussing you out do they even do for domestic flights?
You pass through security, hand luggage, wallet, phone, laptop etc will go into a plastic bucket and through the x-ray. You walk through a metal detector. You may get called aside to have the metal detector wand waved over you, sometimes a pat down, but that is rare. A security pajeet may approach you and ask to swab your hands and bag for residue, this takes a minute. Once that is done then you are airside and can wait at the boarding gate, there is usually no further security. At the boarding gate some airlines (namely Jetstar) can be pedantic about measuring the dimensions of your hand luggage and weighing it. If it is a little over they will want you to check it in and they will probably charge you for that.

To be honest, you will struggle because accessibility infrastructure is very basic and sometimes plain dysfunctional.
For example in Samarkand, you'll be able to visit the Registan complex and the Gur Emir mausoleum without problems, but places like the Shahi-Zinda necropolis will require you to climb stairs like pic related.
Stairs in general will be a problem, many of them are steep, uneven or crooked and they rarely have handrails.

However, the locals are very helpful, especially if you look like you're having difficulties plus it's still cheap enough to hire a private guide+driver, so you'll be able t dictate the pace and only exhaust yourself where it cannot be avoided.

I have multiple friends living as expats in the Netherlands, and most of them complain a lot. The Dutch are very blunt to the point of being rude, and most are disinterested in socializing with foreigners. Although they have some of the best English in Europe it's typical for most to speak only Dutch if there's more than one Dutch person present. You'll probably wind up in a mostly if not entirely-expat bubble. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but it's a thing.

All that said, as a casual visitor I've always had a good time there. You might give it a shot if you can get a company to sponsor you for a work permit (as above seething poster suggests, it's basically impossible for an American to move to Europe without having a job in hand before departure; it's rare to be allowed to come over first and seek work on the ground, and if you try to go that route anyway, you will almost certainly have to leave the country again to get your papers in order at an embassy outside of NL once you have an offer in hand).

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2367167
>Even if you were married to a Dutch girl you wouldn't be able to work there
>wtf? why?
The Dutch just have a slightly tighter version of the universal EU labor law. For an employer to hire a foreigner, first they have to prove that there is no Dutch national available who could do the job. Next they have to prove that there’s nobody from elsewhere in the EU who could do the job. So Americans and all other non-EU foreigners are a distant third in line. Plus, alongside the bureaucratic PITA, it’s much more expensive to import non-EU people, so even if the protectionist policies didn’t exist there would be a big disincentive to bother hiring Yanks.

Not to say that it doesn’t happen. But it happens even less than in other EU countries. You’ve basically either got to be pretty hot shit or get transferred in with a multinational.

last_replies.com:
>>2366676
I have some experience with programs affiliated with the DRH Movement / Humana People to People. They've been running in some form or another since the 1970's. The template is some period of time doing studies/training in Europe or the US, some period of time working in a development project in Africa, and some shorter period of time concluding back in Europe or the US. Currently, it looks like it's 3 months study/prep/training, 6 months at the project, 1 month conclusion.

The work you do at the project will partly depend on your preferences and partly on what's available. I worked in the country office for an HIV prevention program, where I helped with training community health outreach workers and led a knowledge-attitudes-practices survey team. My wife worked with a program for expanding access to clean water in rural areas.

In the past I would have a bit of hesitation to recommend these programs, because the training period used to be 6 months and involved some unpleasant shit. It looks like they just eliminated the bad parts and kept the rest, which is great.

You will run into annoying "save the world" types. You might be one of them. You will also run into people who are doing the program as a fun experience or for their resumes. That's just the type of people who do this stuff.

If you're interested, there are a few different DRH schools running this program-- One World Center in Michigan in the US, College for International Co-Operation and Development in England, Richmond Vale Academy in St. Vincent, DRH Lindersvold in Denmark, and maybe one or two more in Denmark that I've left out.

>>2366528
>Have you ever been to Denali National park?
Yup, road to Fairbanks goes through DNP. The park itself is actually quite large, and the mountain is not near the tourist zone (which is on the highway). If you want to go the mountain, typically you'd either drive on the backroads (they're dirt mostly I thinK), or take a park bus. There are 1 or 2 resorts there, and they'll have electricity, running water, internet, etc. They're quite expensive though ($300+/night?). The tourist zone only operates in summer months; complete ghost town in the winter (also wouldn't recommend driving the road between anchorage/fairbanks in the winter unless you're experienced, it's remote, no cell connection, and cold, ie dangerous.
>How affordable is it to visit Alaska?
Assuming leaving from SF, LA, Seattle, or Portland, round trip flight to anchorage is like $400 economy? Hotels are probably cheaper than what you'd find in downtown major cities in US, maybe $80-$200/night. Food is probably slightly more expensive than any other metro US area. Though, significantly cheaper than other northern cities you'd find in canada, europe, etc. Attractions are mostly outdoors and free, though I believe DNP requires a park pass? Not sure, one isn't needed if you stay in tourist/highway corridor. Rental cars are expensive as fuck. Like $100/day or more.
Public transit outside of the Anchorage and Fairbanks metro areas is basically non-existent, with the exception of the Alaska Railroad, which you should probably look into. It's not super cheap, but it operates all along the Seward Highway, through Anchorage and up to DNP and to Fairbanks. They have sleeper cabins, food, etc.

>>2366530
If you're most concerned with moving to Alaska or DNP, I believe a bunch of the resorts hire international workers for like summer gigs. They give you a place to sleep (or an allowance and you find a place), and then you work at the resort during the day. Similar to a cruise ship, but more freedom.
